title: What do non-resource-gated champs bring to the game?
body:
I posed this question about a year ago, and am interested to see, with the addition of yet another non-resource-gated (NRG) champion, what the community thinks now. 

What value does giving certain champs no resource to manage bring to the game?

Edit: Sorry, I've talked about true non-resource-gated before, so the definition comes naturally to me, but what I'm really talking about are the champs who never have to worry about not being able to use an off-CD skill (barring CC or whatever). Energy, Heat, Health, Mana; all these do not fall under the purview of what I'm talking about.

replies.body:
Some of the values we see in non mana using champions:

* It allows us to create champions with different feeling and acting kits. Shen for example's always going to have to really think about when he Shadow Dashes, given the high cost on it and that's something he can't get around with item purchases (can't buy so much energy the cost becomes irrelevant at some point). 

* It helps create variety of play experience, particularly when it comes to power curves and playstyles over the course of a game. Mana using champions go from being limited in lane to almost always using spells on CD in late game teamfights. Non mana champs, whether Heat, Energy, Fury or CD only, instead have similar limitations across the game, making laning in particular feel pretty different, both as them and against them.

* Removing mana from a champion opens up some potential for interesting team comps. A non mana using mid for example means you're more able to pick a mana heavy jungler or give blue to another lane. 

* Non mana users value many items differently, since the mana and mana regen on them are irrelevant, so favor somewhat different builds, creating variety both for themselves and, to a much lesser extent, other people playing with them. 

There are certainly costs as well of course. Mana's a really useful lever in balancing some abilities, particularly those that give easy wave clear or poke, limiting the amount they can be cast during the early game in particular. Resource management's also a really important skill in LoL (e.g. conserve mana better than lane opponent, bully them out once they're OOM). As a result if removing it from a kit you're going to want to ensure that either the alternate resource offers sufficient skill growth potential or that the rest of the kit has a deep enough mastery curve to not need it.

Most NRG champions also have lower CDs for their abilities compared to their mana counterparts which allows them to either burst faster or clear waves faster than mana champions of equal burst or clear power. If they don't kill their opponent they are put in a weak state due to having to wait for energy/cool off(heat) while their mana (unless near OOM) or manaless counterparts only would have to wait for CDs.

> What value does giving certain champs no resource to manage bring to the game?

In a void? They bring us closer to URF mode.

In a broader sense, it allows champions to have skills that feel more like auto-attacks in power (which are manaless), rather than forcing skills into always using an ammo system that's predominantly there to offset the advantages of front-loading 10 seconds of DPS into 1 second.
If you take a look at manaless champions, you'll generally notice their mana-based equivalents can drop a combo significantly faster and front-load more of their damage.
Riven's ideal rotation involves casting the same skill no less than 3 times along with 2 casts of her ultimate, and optimally an auto-attack between each one of her skill casts. Over a 10 second period of time it's pretty impressive - but Jax, a fairly similar fighter/assassin mix, can unload an empowered strike, leap strike, counter-strike, grandmaster strike, and Tri-Froce proc in a skill+AA reset combo (he also front-loads all his gap-closing to happen at once in a way that doesn't sacrifice damage potential for mobility).
Generally speaking - the combo time for alternate resource champions is much less front-loaded and takes longer to perform/allows more reaction time. Kennen, Vladimir, and Mordekaiser are more DPS mages than bursty, and even Zed and Akali requires a little more set-up and skill casts to unload everything properly than, say, LeBlanc.

Obviously there's a few exceptions, but the justification for manaless usually seems to be sustained damage is at a noteworthy disadvantage compared to burst damage. 
Anyways - I'd say most of the weirdness around manaless being a thing has to do with auto-attacks not costing mana.

It's just that mana tends to lead to comparatively more front-loaded damage than manaless. It's very much an issue of subtle shades of gray.
It's important to compare mages to mages, assassins to assassins, fighters to fighters, and tanks to tanks to see this play out. 

----------

Vladimir and Kennen are obviously bursty when compared to Tryndamere or Kog'Maw, but compared to other mages like Annie or Lux - the 5-stacks on tides of blood, multi-hit Mealstrom ultimate, and comparatively short range of Vlad and Kennen compared to most mages, puts them in far less of a front-loaded damage position than their counterparts and much more of a sustained DPS position. Kennen even has a pretty solid AA steroid that has seen him played as a marksman on occasion.

Or look at Shen vs. Leona. Leona can combo lock-down an opponent with a pretty front-loaded combo. Shen's skills (outside of his no-damage ultimate) are so weak he needs to get off a solid 2 of everything to really come close to the same kind of combo - making his far less front-loaded and stretching it out over a longer period of time.

Or Garen vs. Darius. Darius can front-load his trading damage in Decimate, exposing himself to danger for a very minimal amount of time and even getting some no-risk DPS via his passive. Meanwhile Garen's Judgement requires Garen sticking within melee range of an opponent for 3 seconds - big difference in front-loaded power compared to the ~0.5 seconds Darius needs to cast his skill.

Good response. There is definitely a trend towards no burst damage from NRG champs. The problem I find that this brings, though, is a much more powerful laning phase, since that phase tends to favor the champs who can harass repeatedly. Teamfights are definitely tilted towards burst damage, but almost every one of these NRG champs are major lane bullies, especially the ones with built in sustain. That baffled my mind, earlier in S4, when they said they wanted Renekton to be the top lane balance bar, even though he has a core mechanic that less than 10% of champs exhibit. How do you feel about that aspect, and what are your thoughts on the health of NRG sustain champs in general?

Well - strong in lane and weak in team fights is a reasonable statistical and balanced trade-off IMO.

Annoying to no end when you're starting out and learning the game, because picking a fight 1v1 isn't something every champion is actually balanced around.
But pretty interesting for the broader scope of the game due to strategic and itemization/customization it brings.

Also - strong lane/weak late champions, or strong duel/weak team-fight champions tend to force a lot more map movement and interesting, split-up action - leading to split-push and pick strategies. Manaless champions help push this kind of diversity a little more than mana based champions due to that strong lane/duel dynamic.

I suppose I could have been a little more clear, but non-resource-gated means champs who don't expend any resource (or generate heat, as is Rumble's case) when they cast a spell. The question to ask to verify is "will there ever be a time that they can't cast a spell when it's off cooldown and not under any outside effects?" Health, energy, heat, mana. All those are already good and healthy in my mind. It's the remaining ones who tend towards problematic laning phases in particular.

Those are nice advantages, but what about the negative value?  Especially on the champions that can harass at range, is it at all healthy when they can do it without meaningful consequence?

That's definitely the most common response. The usual counter is that these entry level champs are supposed to be generally weaker to push players to learn the harder champs, but many of these NRG champs are actually very viable; actually Reketon was set as the top lane balance bar in S4. The problem with your point is that, in order to be entry level and a learning tool, with all player skill and familiarity level being the same, NRG champs should be weaker than resource champs to push those who wish to really succeed at this game upwards.

I don't view it as a question of power, I view it as a question of consistency.  Resource gated champions (at least some) should have the option of consciously choosing periods of time within which they spam their skills like crazy for moments of high-efficacy, at the expense of a trip back to base or mana-regen downtime and low ability usage.  It's a strategic decision.

Non-resource gated champions are able to use their rotations at their leisure, bringing consistency and reliability (they can always perform at a certain level) without the option of ramping up their power due to strategic necessity.
